sentences: Snoh Sheri Nowrozi (born Shahrzad Fooladi, 13 September 1987), better known by her stage name, Snoh Aalegra (), is a Swedish singer and songwriter based in Los Angeles.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut album Feels was released in 2017, followed by Ugh, Those Feels Again in 2019.

section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: Aalegra was born on 13 September 1987 in Uppsala, Sweden to Persian parents.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She grew up in Enköping, Sweden, moving there with her mother following her parents' divorce.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: They later moved to Stockholm.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She began writing music at the age of 9.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In 2001, at the age of 13, Aalegra signed an artist development deal with Sony Music Sweden.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: She would ultimately leave Sony Sweden with no music being released.
section: == Life and career == | === 1987–2008: Early life and career beginnings ===

sentences: In 2009, Aalegra began her musical career using the mononym Sheri.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: She released her debut single "Hit and Run" on 16 February 2009, with production by Andreas Carlsson.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: The single peaked at number 12 on the Swedish Single Charts.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: She released her second single "U Got Me
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: Good" on 4 December 2009, reaching number 2 on the Swedish Single Charts.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: On 6 April 2010, under the name Sheri, she released the studio album First Sign, on Universal Music Sweden.
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: It features a cover of the 1984 song "Smooth Operator" by Sade, and the singles "Hit And Run" and "U Got Me Good".
section: == Life and career == | === 2009–2013: Career beginnings as Sheri, First Sign ===

sentences: She signed with No I.D.'s ARTium Recordings in 2013.

== Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: In July 2014, she debuted her new name, Snoh Aalegra, and appeared on Common's tenth studio album, Nobody's Smiling, featuring on the song "Hustle Harder".
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: She released her debut single, "Bad Things" featuring Common, in October 2014, and  her debut EP, There Will Be Sunshine, on 17 November 2014 through ARTium/Epic.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: The EP includes "Stockholm, Pt. II (Outro)" featuring Cocaine 80s.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: In 2014, she became a protégé of Prince after he discovered her music and reached out to her.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: He mentored her until his death in 2016.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: In February 2015, Aalegra said she had changed her legal name to Snoh Nowrozi.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: She added "Aalegra" to her stage name because it means "joyful" in Italian (changing the spelling of "allegra" to make it her own), and because there was already an artist named Snoh.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: On 11 February 2015, Aalegra released her first single as Snoh Aalegra, "Emotional", produced by RZA.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: She also appeared on Vince Staples' debut album, Summertime '06 in June 2015, providing vocals for the song, "Jump Off the Roof".
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: Aalegra released the EP Don't Explain on 8 April 2016 through ARTium Recordings, with features and production from James Fauntleroy, No I.D., Boi-1da, Christian Rich and DJ Dahi.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: The EP features a cover of the 1944 song, "Don't Explain" by Billie Holiday and Arthur Herzog Jr. John Mayer plays guitar on "Under the Influence", and the final track, "Chaos", was written by Sia.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: In 2017, she went on her first North American tour, in support of Daniel Caesar.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: On 20 October 2017, Aalegra released her debut album, Feels, with features from Vince Staples, Vic Mensa, Logic, and Timbuktu.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: The album is a "nostalgic blend of soul and R&B" which she calls "cinematic soul".
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: Her single "Time" was sampled by Drake on "Do Not Disturb", the closing track on his 2017 mixtape More Life.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: On September 12, 2018, her single "Nothing Burns Like the Cold" produced by Christian Rich and featuring Vince Staples, was used by Apple for their iPhone XS announcement video and commercials.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: In the fall of 2018, Aalegra headlined her first North American tour with support from Mereba and Leven Kali.
section: == Life and career == | === 2014–2018: Debut as Snoh Aalegra, Feels ===

sentences: === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: In August 2019, Aalegra released her second album, Ugh, Those Feels Again, on ARTium Recordings.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: The album is considered to be a sequel to Feels, similar in mood and thematically.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: The album peaked at number 3 on the Billboard R&B Album Sales chart, number 6 on the Billboard Top R&B Albums chart, and number 73 on the Billboard 200 chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: The single "I Want You Around" reached number 1 on the Billboard Adult R&B Songs chart.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: She recorded the song "Wolves Are Out Tonight", produced by Swizz Beatz, for the soundtrack to the 2019 EPIX television series Godfather of Harlem.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: She released the video to her single "Whoa", starring herself and actor Michael B. Jordan, on December 13, 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: In the fall of 2019, she headlined a European and North American tour, with support from Baby Rose and Giveon, and reached number 1 on the Bandsintown + Billboard Global Rising Artists Index.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: In February 2020, NPR's Tiny Desk Concerts released Aalegra's performance where she sang "Love Like That", "I Want You Around", "Whoa", "Fool For You", and "Find Someone Like You".
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: On 9 March 2020, it was announced that Aalegra had signed a recording contract with Roc Nation/Universal Music Group with a partnership with her current label ARTium Records, and released "Dying 4 Your Love", her first single, through both labels on July 10.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: She announced that she was working on her next album in an interview.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: Aalegra was featured on "Last Time", on Giveon's second EP, When It's All Said and Done.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: On 9 July 2021, Aalegra released her third album, Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies, on ARTium Records and Roc Nation.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===

sentences: The album was preceded by singles "Dying 4 Your Love", released on 10 June 2020, and "Lost You", released 21 June 2021, which was produced by Maneesh and No I.D.
section: == Life and career == | === 2019–present: Ugh, Those Feels Again and Temporary Highs in the Violet Skies ===
